title: Recreations of Christopher North, Volume 2
author: Wilson, John
snippet: All the way up its river, Loch Levenwould be fair, were it only for her hanging woods.

title: Recreations of Christopher North, Volume 2
author: Wilson, John
snippet: All round about Ballahulish and Invercothe scenery of Loch Leven is the sweetest ever seen overshadowed bysuch mountains; the deeper their gloom, the brighter its lustre; in allweathers it wears a cheerful smile; and often while tip among the rocksthe tall trees are tossing in the storm, the heart of the woods beneathis calm, and the vivid fields they shelter look as if they still enjoyedthe sun.

title: Recreations of Christopher North, Volume 2
author: Wilson, John
snippet: It is indeed one of those on which nature haslavished all her infinite varieties of loveliness; but Loch Leven isscarcely less fair, and perhaps grander; and there is matchlessmagnificence above Loch Etive.

title: The Antiquary - Volume 01
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: "I am surprised to hear you, Mr. Oldbuck: you know, or ought to know,that the list of these potentates was copied by Henry Maule of Melguin,from the Chronicles of Loch Leven and St. Andrews, and put forth by himin his short but satisfactory history of the Picts, printed by RobertFreebairn of Edinburgh, and sold by him at his shop in the ParliamentClose, in the, year of God seventeen hundred and five, or six, I am notprecisely certain whichbut I have a copy at home that stands next to mytwelvemo copy of the Scots Acts, and ranges on the shelf with them verywell.

title: Song and scenery;
author: Moffat, James C.
snippet: From the point where Loch Leven sets off to the east.

title: Song and scenery;
author: Moffat, James C.
snippet: At Ballahulish, on Loch Leven, we landed, and went up to Glencoe, interesting for its own savage grandeur ; for its river, said to be the Cona of Ossian ; and for the terrible massacre of its population,  a sept of the clan Macdonald, about one

title: Song and scenery;
author: Moffat, James C.
snippet: One of those to the east is Loch Etive, which we have passed, and further up is Loch Leven.

title: Four years in Great Britain.
author: Colton, Calvin
snippet: The coach from Stirling to Perth, by the way of Dollar and Milnathort, passes in full view of Loch Leven, that placid sheet of water, in the midst of which are the island and ruins of the castle where Queen Mary was incarcerated,  and from which she made her escape with Douglass, May 2d, 1568.

title: Notes of foreign travel.
author: Bates, James Hale
snippet: This castle of Loch Leven dates back beyond authentic history,, and is attributed to Congal.

title: Notes of foreign travel.
author: Bates, James Hale
snippet: streets to an old and comfortable inn, where we dine well, the famous Loch Leven trout figuring on the bill of fare.

title: Notes of foreign travel.
author: Bates, James Hale
snippet: — Left on g.30 train for Loch Leven, crossing the Firth of Forth by a ferry — five miles — to Burntisland, thence on by rail through Kirkcaldy, where Carlyle and Irving once taught separate schools.

title: Gray Days and Gold ... New edition, revised, with illustrations
author: Winter, William
snippet: at which she rested, on the romantic and memorableoccasion of her flight from Loch Leven.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: We thought the country rather uninteresting, except so far as the well-tilled fieldsattracted our attention, until we drew nearto Kinross—a neat town on the border ofLoch Leven.

title: Rambles in Europe ... With historical facts relating to Scotch-American families, gathered in Scotland and the North of Ireland ... Illustrated
author: Morrison, Leonard Allison.

title: Recollections of a Visit to Glasgow with the British Archæological Associations, August 27th to September 5th, 1888. With notes
